<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 587, 212, 601]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 728, 634]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[55, 32, 415, 67]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 128, 88]]<|/det|> Data <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 100, 690, 530]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall\(g\) = 9.81 m s⁻²
speed of light in free space\(c\) = 3.00 x 10⁸ m s⁻¹
elementary charge\(e\) = 1.60 x 10⁻¹⁹ C
unified atomic mass unit1 u = 1.66 x 10⁻²⁷ kg
rest mass of proton\(m_p\) = 1.67 x 10⁻²⁷ kg
rest mass of electron\(m_e\) = 9.11 x 10⁻³¹ kg
Avogadro constant\(N_A\) = 6.02 x 10²³ mol⁻¹
molar gas constant\(R\) = 8.31 J K⁻¹ mol⁻¹
Boltzmann constant\(k\) = 1.38 x 10⁻²³ J K⁻¹
gravitational constant\(G\) = 6.67 x 10⁻¹¹ N m² kg⁻²
permittivity of free space\(\varepsilon_0\) = 8.85 x 10⁻¹² F m⁻¹
Planck constant\(h\) = 6.63 x 10⁻³⁴ J s
Stefan-Boltzmann constant\(\sigma\) = 5.67 x 10⁻⁸ W m⁻² K⁻⁴
<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 566, 170, 581]]<|/det|> Formulae <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 594, 615, 850]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion\(s\) = ut + ½at²
\(v^2\) = u² + 2as
hydrostatic pressure\(\Delta p\) = ρgΔh
uptrust\(F\) = ρgV
Doppler effect for sound waves\(f_0\) = \(f_s V\)
\(V \pm V_s\)
electric current\(I\) = Anvq
resistors in series\(R\) = \(R_1 + R_2 + ...\)
resistors in parallel\(1/R\) = \(1/R_1 + 1/R_2 + ...\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 98, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 136, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 285, 88]]<|/det|>
Define velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 134, 866, 150]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 166, 136, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 918, 198]]<|/det|>
In an experiment, two objects A and B are released from the side of a building, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 788, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[409, 503, 589, 519]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 534, 780, 550]]<|/det|>
<pre>Object A is released from rest at a height of 10.0 m above horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 551, 917, 598]]<|/det|>
<pre>Object B is released with an initial upward velocity of \(3.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at a height \(h\) above the ground. Both objects take the same time to reach the ground and they do not collide with each other. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 612, 257, 628]]<|/det|>
<pre>Calculate \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[557, 765, 826, 781]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h = ............................................................. m\) [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[920, 937, 952, 964]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 72, 136, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
In a second experiment, object B is released from the same height as in (b) but with a speed of \(6.0 \text{ m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the vertical, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[353, 116, 645, 250]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[468, 297, 533, 313]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 327, 184, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 327, 917, 359]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the time taken for object B to reach the ground is less than, the same as, or greater than the time taken in the first experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 435, 866, 451]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 465, 184, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 465, 917, 497]]<|/det|>
By considering energy, state and explain whether the speed at which object B reaches the ground is less than, the same as, or greater than in the first experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[844, 603, 916, 619]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 72, 136, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 515, 88]]<|/det|>
Define the moment of a force about a pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 166, 136, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 166, 918, 198]]<|/det|>
Three objects A, B and C are placed on a horizontal beam. The beam is in equilibrium, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 810, 383]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[409, 400, 589, 416]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 431, 505, 447]]<|/det|>
The beam is uniform and has length 9.0 m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 449, 468, 464]]<|/det|>
A pivot is at the midpoint of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 465, 615, 480]]<|/det|>
Object A has mass 90 kg and is at one end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 481, 671, 496]]<|/det|>
Object B has mass \(m\) and is a distance of 3.0 m from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 497, 671, 512]]<|/det|>
Object C has mass 150 kg and is at the other end of the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 526, 184, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 526, 301, 542]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 728, 885, 744]]<|/det|>
<form>\(m = ............................................................ kg\) [3]

<label>DO NOT WRITE IN THIS MARGIN</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 945, 546, 957]]<|/det|>
9702/23/M/J/25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 184, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Object A is removed and replaced by a wire fixed to the end of the beam and to the ground, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 115, 870, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 272, 533, 288]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 2.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 302, 920, 334]]<|/det|>
After the change, the beam is again horizontal and in equilibrium. The positions of B and C are unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 348, 772, 380]]<|/det|>
The wire has a diameter of \(1.8 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}\) and has a strain of \(1.2 \times 10^{-3}\). The wire is not extended beyond its limit of proportionality.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 395, 533, 411]]<|/det|>
Calculate the Young modulus of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[438, 581, 885, 597]]<|/det|>
<form>Young modulus = ....................................................... $Pa$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 581, 885, 597]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 611, 184, 627]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 611, 918, 643]]<|/det|>
Object B is now moved to a new position closer to the pivot without passing it. The beam is again horizontal and in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 660, 785, 676]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, that this has on the strain in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[844, 782, 920, 798]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 917, 104]]<|/det|>
A car of mass 1500 kg is travelling along a straight horizontal road at constant velocity \(v\). The car is subject to a total resistive force \(F\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 293, 532, 309]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 325, 918, 358]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 369, 532, 385]]<|/det|>
\[
P=Fv .
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 573, 136, 589]]<|/det|>

the air resistance acting on the car

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 604, 918, 636]]<|/det|>
<pre>A screen is parallel to the grating. An interference pattern is seen on the screen and the angle between the second-order maxima is \(52^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 398, 485, 414]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[555, 582, 885, 598]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 101, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
A nichrome resistance wire has length \(150cm\), cross-sectional area \(2.45\times 10^{-7}m^{2}\) and resistivity \(1.12\times 10^{-6}\Omega m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 119, 136, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 680, 135]]<|/det|>
Calculate, to three significant figures, the resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 273, 882, 289]]<|/det|>
<form>resistance = ..................................................... $\Omega$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 305, 136, 321]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 917, 337]]<|/det|>
The nichrome wire forms part of a potentiometer circuit together with a cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 1.2V and negligible internal resistance, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 349, 756, 574]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[409, 592, 589, 608]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 7.1 (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 622, 576, 638]]<|/det|>
<pre>The circuit is used to determine the e.m.f. of cell X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 653, 918, 685]]<|/det|>
<pre>The galvanometer is used in a null method to find the null point 64 cm from the left-hand end of the nichrome wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 700, 184, 716]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 700, 520, 716]]<|/det|>
Explain what is meant by a null method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 764, 916, 780]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 184, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 433, 89]]<|/det|>
Calculate the e.m.f. of cell X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 228, 885, 244]]<|/det|>
<form>e.m.f. = ....................................................... V [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[147, 258, 184, 274]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 258, 918, 291]]<|/det|>
The cell of e.m.f. 1.2 V is replaced by a new cell with the same e.m.f. but with an internal resistance that is not negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 304, 918, 336]]<|/det|>
State and explain the effect, if any, of the internal resistance of the new cell on the position of the null point.
